overview__hs__subheading.text: Securely and easily add location data to applications

overview__wal__feature_1__label.text: Access cost-effective, high-quality geospatial data from trusted data providers.

overview__wal__feature_2__label.text: Protect user privacy, shield your sensitive information, and reduce your application's security risks.

overview__wal__feature_3__label.text: Quickly deploy and accelerate application development with seamless integrations with AWS services.

overview__wal__feature_4__label.text: Easily integrate geospatial data into an applications for different use cases or geographies with data from multiple providers.

overview__routes__subheading.text: Find and plan optimized routes with estimated time and distance

overview__geofences__subheading.text: Define virtual boundaries. Detect entry or exit events

overview__etlb__label_1.text: Get started with Amazon Location today.

overview__etlb__label_2.text: Three months free with the AWS Free Tier.

product__subheading.text: Discover Amazon Location tools you need to build location-based services and applications that can be used to find nearby places, get directions, and display real-time traffic updates.

product__places__product_1__info.text: Geocodes free-form text, such as an address, name, city, or region to allow you to search for Places or points of interest.

product__places__product_2__info.text: Reverse geocodes a given coordinate and returns a legible address.

product__places__product_3__info.text: Generates suggestions for addresses and points of interest based on partial or misspelled free-form text.

product__places__product_4__info.text: Finds details of a place by its unique PlaceId. A PlaceId is returned by other search operations.

product__maps__product_1__info.text: Retrieves glyphs used to display labels on a map. Glyphs is a binary file containing encoded Unicode characters.

product__maps__product_2__info.text: Retrieves glyphs used to display labels on a map. Glyphs is a binary file containing encoded Unicode characters.

product__maps__product_3__info.text: Retrieves the map style descriptor from a map resource. Map style defines color and other style information for the data to define how it will look when rendered.

product__maps__product_4__info.text: Retrieves a vector data tile. A Map tile format stores map data using vector shapes and used by a map renderer client to render a map.

product__routes__product_1__info.text: Calculates routes between an origin and a destination, with up to 23 waypoints along the route, for different modes of transportation, avoidances, and traffic conditions.

product__routes__product_2__info.text: Generates matrix from a set of departure positions to a set of destination positions. Useful as inputs into route planning or optimization software.

product__geofences__product_1__info.text: Create, Read, Update and Delete a Geofence Collection. A geofence Collection contains zero or more geofences.

product__geofences__product_2__info.text: Create, Read, Update and Delete a Geofence. Geofence is polygon geometry that defines a virtual boundary on a map.

product__geofences__product_3__info.text: Stores or Deletes a batch of geofences from a geofence collection.

product__geofences__product_4__info.text: Evaluates device positions against the geofence geometries from a given geofence collection. Also, sends notifications when it determines if the device has entered or exited a geofenced area.

product__trackers__product_1__info.text: Create, Read, Update and Delete a Tracker. Trackers help retrieve current and historical location of devices.

product__trackers__product_2__info.text: Association or disassociate a tracker resource from a geofence collection.

product__trackers__product_3__info.text: Retrieves most recent position of device(s)

product__trackers__product_4__info.text: Retrieves the device(s) position history within a specified range of time.

help__subheading.text: Detailed instructions for creating, deleting and troubleshooting the Demo app's stack.

help__item_1__desc.text: Running a CloudFormation template via your own AWS account to configure a stack which creates all the necessary resources.

help__item_1__content_1.text: Open sidebar on demo page and click on [click here] link to get redirected to AWS console.

help__item_1__content_2.text: Once redirected, if your AWS isn't logged in, you'll be asked to login.

help__item_1__content_3.text: After login you'll be taken to CloudFormation create stack step and you'd notice that Amazon S3 URL field is prefilled. Click on Next.

help__item_1__content_4.text: On the next step enter any email address in CognitoUserEmail field, you'll be sent a temporary password on this email, which will be later used to login into the applicatoin using Amazon Hosted UI. Click on Next.

help__item_1__content_5.text: Do not modify any config on the next couple of steps and simply proceed by clicking Next, until you are presented with the Submit button, here accept the acknowledgement and press Submit.

help__item_1__content_6.text: You'll see that the stack is now being created, depending on you internet speed this step can take from 5 to 10 minutes. Once the stack creation is completed, go to Outputs tab.

help__item_1__content_7.text: Copy and paste all the values into the form. Make sure all values are copied correctly to ensure a successful connection. Click on Connect.

help__item_1__content_8.text: If you encounter any error, make sure that all the values copied from step 6 are correct and try again, once succeeded, you'd notice a success state.

help__item_1__content_9.text: You can now either continue to use Maps, Places and Routes funtionality or sign in to use Geofence and Tracking functionality. Use the email you entered in step 4 and enter the temporary password that you received on that email.

help__item_1__content_10.text: You'd be asked to updated your temporary password if you are using the credentials for the first time.

help__item_1__content_11.text: After you have successfully logged in, you'd notice in the sidebar that Geofence and Tracking functionality is now unlocked/enabled.

help__item_2__content_1.text: Make sure you have signed out of the application.

help__item_2__content_2.text: After signing out, make sure to Disconnect AWS Account.

help__item_2__content_3.text: Once disconnected, go to AWS Console and search for CloudFormation.

help__item_2__content_5.text: After selecting the above mentioned stack, Click on Delete.

help__item_3__desc.text: Ways to resolve possible issues that could arise while deleting a stack. Such as corruption of stack.

help__item_3__content_1.text: Sometimes the stack might fail to be deleted successfully.

help__item_3__content_2.text: In that case, search for IoT Core in the search box and open it.

help__item_3__content_3.text: In the left sidebar, select Policies under Security and select AmazonLocationIotPolicy and click on Delete.

help__item_3__content_5.text: Go back to CloudFormation service, select amazon-location-resource-setup stack and click on Delete.

help__item_3__content_6.text: A confirmation popup would appear asking if you'd like to retain resources, without checking anything, click on Delete stack, after a few minutes the stack should be deleted successfully.

sa__ad__30.text: you can use the version history to work this out, if this matters to you. Instead, we intend that those contributors who later modified the file, agree to release their changes under the Apache license. The conventional way of signifying this is to duplicate the Apache headers at the top of each file each time a change is made by a different author, but this would quickly become impractical.

sa__ad__31.text: Where the copyright header says something like:

sa__ad__32.text: // Copyright 2013 Johns Hopkins University (author: Daniel Povey)

sa__ad__33.text: it is because the individual who wrote the code was at that institution as an employee, so the copyright is owned by the university (and we will have checked that the contributions were in accordance with the open-source policies of the institutions concerned, including getting them vetted individually where necessary). From a legal point of view the copyright ownership is that of the institution concerned, and the (author: xxx) in parentheses is just informational, to identify the actual person who wrote the code, and is not intended to have any legal implications.  In some cases, however, particularly early on, we just wrote the name of the university or company concerned, without the actual author's name in parentheses. If you see something like

sa__ad__35.text: it does not imply that Arnab was working for Microsoft, it is because someone else contributed to the file while working at Microsoft (this would be Daniel Povey, in fact, who was working at Microsoft Research at the outset of the project).

sa__ad__36.text: The list of authors of each file is in an essentially arbitrary order, but is often chronological if they contributed in different years.

sa__ad__155.text: While Xiph.Org, Broadcom, and Microsoft filed IPR disclosures giving royalty-free licenses to their patents used in Opus, four companies that did not directly participate in the development of Opus, Qualcomm, Huawei, France Telecom, and Ericsson, filed IPR disclosures with potentially royalty-bearing terms. The IETF allows anyone (and their dog) to file an IPR disclosures if they think that their patents “covers or may ultimately cover” a standard. In fact, for any organization who can be said to have contributed in any (very loosely defined) way, these IPR statements are not just allowed, but required. It is thus safer for organisations to declare as much as they can. As an example, one can find similar non-free Qualcomm IPR statements on both SIP and SDP. To our advantage, however, the IETF IPR disclosure policies require companies to provide the actual patent numbers. This allows anyone to verify these claims for themselves, which is definitely a good thing.

sa__ad__156.text: When it comes to patents, it is difficult to say much without making lawyers nervous. However, we can say something quite direct: external counsel Dergosits & Noah has advised us that Opus can be implemented without the need to license the patents disclosed by Qualcomm, Huawei, France Telecom, or Ericsson. We can also say that Mozilla is confident enough in Opus to ship it to hundreds of millions of Firefox users. Similarly, Cisco and Google are also supporting Opus in some products. More companies are expected to do the same soon.

sa__ad__157.text: Mozilla invested significant legal resources into avoiding known patent thickets when designing Opus. Whenever possible, we used processes and methods that have been long known in the field and which are considered patent-free. In addition, we filed numerous patent applications on the new things we invented to help defend the Opus community. As a result, Opus is available on a royalty-free basis and can be deployed by anyone, including other open-source projects. Everyone knows this is an incredibly challenging legal environment to operate in, but we think we’ve succeeded.

Log out if you wish to continue running the Demo App using resources in AWS’s demo app account.

web_based_map_application_description.text: This section showcases a mini web application's cost that uses map tiles API to fetch map tiles and render them in collaboration with MapLibre, allowing user to use search on the map and fetch places along with place details. Furthermore it also allows the user to calculate route between any two positions. This gives an estimate of what your total cost for API consumption would be, assuming that your application uses GetMapTile, SearchPlaceIndexForSuggestions, GetPlace and CalculateRoute APIs.

trackers_and_geofences_application_descr.text: Amazon Location Service provides trackers and geofences capabilities that can be added to your application. With trackers, you can instantly retrieve current and historical location of devices uploaded from your tracked devices or assets. Geofences gives your application the ability to detect and act when a tracked device enters or exits a geographical boundary you define as a geofence. When a breach of the geofence is detected, Amazon Location Service automatically sends the entry or exit event to Amazon EventBridge, which can then trigger downstream actions.
1) Trackers write cost is based on the usage of BatchUpdateDevicePosition API, which allows you to record and store the trackers history of a device.
2) Geofences cost is based on the BatchEvaluateGeofences API, which evaluates tracked position against a geofence for entered or exited events.
3) Trackers read cost is based on ListDevicePositions API, which allows you to fetch the device's recent position history.

geofence_driven_tooltip.text: These inputs help you estimate the total cost for Geofence Evaluation. Location updates from devices may include noises, jitters, or data points not useful for geofence evaluation, such identical or similar locations when the device is stationary or moving at low speed. Amazon Location Trackers Service provides multiple filters to help you remove irrelevant location updates to reduce the cost of Geofence Evaluation.

dynamic_maps_description.text: Google Maps pricing varies for API calls made via its SDKs; however, our approach with Amazon Location SDKs, which are free, ensures consistency. Regardless of the platform, all Amazon Location SDKs use the same set of REST APIs, resulting in a unified and consistent pricing structure. The APIs and SDKs of Amazon Location Service work with MapLibre.

migrateAWebApp_heading.text: Web - Migrating from Google Maps to Amazon Location Service

migrateAWebApp_desc.text: This guide details the technical process for transitioning web applications from Google Maps to Amazon Location Service. It highlights initial setup, Amazon Location resource configuration, and provides SDK comparison examples to facilitate the integration of mapping functionalities into web-based platforms.

migrateAWebApp_article_description.text: If migrating an existing web application, check to see if it's using an open-source map control library. Examples of open-source map control library are: Cesium, Leaflet, and OpenLayers. You can still migrate your application, even if it uses an open-source map control library, and you don't want to use the Azure Maps Web SDK. In such case, connect your application to the Azure Maps tile services (road tiles | satellite tiles). The following points detail on how to use Azure Maps in some commonly used open-source map control libraries.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_description.text: Make sure to complete the following steps before completing the examples.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_2_a.text: Navigate to the <0>Maps section</0> in the Amazon Location Service console and click 'Create Map' to preview available map styles.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_2_b.text: Give the new map resource a name and description. Remember the name you assign to this map resource, which will be used later in the tutorial.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_2_c.text: When choosing a map style, choose the map data provider. Refer to section 82 of the <0>AWS service terms</0> for more details.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_2_d.text: Read and accept the <0>Amazon Location Terms</0>, then click 'Create Map'. After you have created the map, you can interact with it by zooming in, out, or panning in any direction.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_3.text: Select the place index you wish to use

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_3_a.text: Navigate to the <0>Place indexes</0> page within the Amazon Location Service console and click 'Create Place Index'.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_3_b.text: Provide a name and description for the new place index resource. Remember the name you assign to this place index resource, which will be used later in the tutorial.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_3_c.text: Select a data provider, ideally aligning with your chosen map provider, to ensure search compatibility with the maps. Refer to section 82 of the <0>AWS service terms</0> for more details.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_3_d.text: Choose the Data storage option. As no data is stored for this tutorial, select 'No, single use only'.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_3_e.text: Read and accept the <0>Amazon Location Terms</0>, then click 'Create Place Index'.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_4.text: Select the route calculator you wish to use

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_4_a.text: In the Amazon Location Service console, navigate to the <0>Route calculators page</0> and click 'Create Route Calculator'.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_4_b.text: Provide a name and description for the new route calculator resource. Remember the name assigned to this route calculator resource, which will be used later in the tutorial.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_4_c.text: Select a data provider, ensuring alignment with the chosen map style and map data provider. Refer to section 82 of the <0>AWS service terms</0> for further information.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_4_d.text: Read and accept the <0>Amazon Location Terms</0>, then click 'Create Route Calculator'.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_a.text: Navigate to the <0>Amazon Location console</0> and select "API keys" from the left-hand menu.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_b.text: Click on the 'Create API key'. The API key must be in the same AWS account and region as the previously created Amazon Location Service resources.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_c.text: Fill in the required details on the 'Create API key' page:

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_c_i.text: Name: Provide a name for your API key, like 'MyAppKey'.

Resources: Choose the Amazon Location Service Map and Place index resources created earlier. You can add multiple resources by selecting 'Add Resource'. This allows the API key to be used with specified resources.

Actions: Specify authorized actions for this API key. At a minimum, select <1>geo:GetMap</1>, <1>geo:SearchPlaceIndexForText</1>, and <1>geo:CalculateRoute</1> to ensure the tutorial functions as intended.
Optionally, you can add a Description, Expiration time, Tags, or a referer (example.com) to limit the key's usage to a specific domain, enabling the tutorial to function only within that domain.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_d.text: Click 'Create API Key' to generate the API key.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_e.text: Select 'Show API Key' and copy the key value (<1>v1.public.a1b2c3d4...</1>) for later use in the tutorial.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_alert.text: For more information on authentication in Amazon Location, see <0>manage authentication</0> in Amazon Location.

notableDifferences_point2.text: Handling Coordinates in Amazon Location Maps:

webSdkExamples_description.text: This guide features code samples tailored for web-based migration, each addressing common use cases. Its purpose is to assist in migrating your web application from Google Maps V3 JavaScript SDK to Amazon Location Service using <0>MapLibre</0>. The provided code snippets for web applications are specifically in JavaScript.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_description.text: Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service allow you to integrate interactive, customizable maps into your applications. These maps can display various types of geographical data and allow for features like panning and zooming.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_point1.text: Google Maps uses <1>google.maps.Map</1> to render maps.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses MapLibre's <1>maplibregl.Map</1> to render maps.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_point1.text: Google Maps uses <1>google.maps.Marker</1> to render markers on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses MapLibre's <1>maplibregl.Marker</1> to render markers on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_descripti.text: You can draw lines on Google Maps. For Amazon Location Service, You can draw them with GeoJSON via MapLibre.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_point1.text: You can use Google Maps Shapes class to draw lines and polygons via <1>google.maps.Polyline</1>.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses the MapLibre library. You can use the <1>addSource</1> and <1>addLayer</1> methods to add GeoJSON data.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_descriptio.text: You can draw polygons on Google Maps. For Amazon Location Service, You can draw them with GeoJSON via MapLibre.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_point1.text: You can use the Google Maps Shapes class to draw lines and polygons via <1>google.maps.Polygon</1>.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses the MapLibre library. You can use the <1>addSource</1> and <1>addLayer</1> methods to add GeoJSON data.

codeSnippets_display_an_info_window_desc.text: Google Maps and Amazon Location Service can render an info/popup on the map.

codeSnippets_display_an_info_window_poin.text: Google Maps uses <1>google.maps.InfoWindow</1> to display a popup next to a marker.
Amazon Location Service uses MapLibre to display a popup via <1>maplibregl.Popup</1>.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_descriptio.text: Google Maps supports data layer functionality, allowing you to overlay data on the map. Amazon Location Service also allows adding data layers via MapLibre.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_point1.text: Google Maps provides a heatmap layer as part of the <1>google.maps.visualization</1> library.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses MapLibre's <1>addLayer</1> function. Typically, you'd first add a source using <1>addSource</1>, then add a layer referencing this source.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_point3.text: The code snippet below showcases displaying a heatmap.

codeSnippets_places_search_post_descript.text: Google Maps offers a Geocoding API for converting between addresses and geographic coordinates. Amazon Location Service also provides Geocoding and Reverse Geocoding capabilities within their Places API, which you can use to get data based on longitude and latitude and vice versa.

codeSnippets_routing_services_descriptio.text: Google Maps and Amazon Location Service both provide routing services.

codeSnippets_routing_services_point1.text: Google Maps provides <1>DirectionsService</1> and <1>DirectionsRenderer</1> or <1>ComputeRoutes</1> and <1>Polyline</1> to calculate and display route data on the map.

codeSnippets_routing_services_point2.text: Amazon Location provides <1>CalculateRouteCommand</1> via its location client and uses Maplibre's rendering capability to display that data on a map.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_descriptio.text: Both services allow the drawing of circular polygon on the map.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_point1.text: Google Maps provides <1>google.maps.Circle</1> to draw a circular polygon.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses Maplibre’s <1>addSource</1> and <1>addLayer</1> methods to render a circular polygon and you can use <1>turf.circle</1> from <0>Turf.js</0> to convert a circle to a polygon for rendering.

codeSnippets_marker_clustering_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses MapLibre’s base class to cluster markers; however, you can use custom logic to render markers and data layers directly from MapLibre via <1>addSource</1> and <1>addLayer</1>.

integrating_the_amazon_location_sdk_desc.text: <1>MapLibre</1> is a free-to-use TypeScript library designed for effortlessly displaying interactive maps on your website. It stands out for its exceptional performance, thanks to cutting-edge technology that accelerates the rendering of vector tiles using your device's graphics processing unit (GPU). This ensures a smooth and responsive map-viewing experience for your website visitors. MapLibre makes it easy to integrate and showcase dynamic maps while delivering high-performance mapping capabilities. Integrating Amazon Location SDK with MapLibre is a crucial step in making your application 'location-aware'. It allows your app to understand and use location information effectively. With this integration, you can do things like:

If you're a developer looking to explore the different SDK programming language options available for integrating Amazon Location Service into your application, you can find detailed information by clicking <0>here</0>. This will help you choose the right SDK that fits the specific needs of your project.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_postDescrip.text: These marker-plotting capabilities enable developers to create interactive, location-aware applications that can guide users to specific points of interest, highlight geographical data, or provide location-based services.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_about.text: Loading a map displays geographical data on a web page or app. By connecting to a map service like Google Maps or Amazon Location Service, users can interact with markers, overlays, and geolocation services to explore and navigate the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_about.text: Displaying a marker places an icon on a map to indicate a location of interest. Markers highlight places like businesses or landmarks. They enhance navigation, geolocation, and provide valuable information for users interacting with the map.

codeSnippets_marker_clustering_about.text: Marker clustering is a technique used to group nearby markers on a map into clusters, improving visual clarity and performance. Instead of cluttering the map with individual markers, clusters represent multiple markers at different zoom levels, making it easier for users to navigate and understand crowded areas on the map.

codeSnippets_display_an_info_window_abou.text: Displaying an info popup is a feature that displays additional information when a user interacts with a marker on a map. When a user clicks or hovers over a marker, a popup window appears, providing details such as address, description, or other relevant data related to the location on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_about.text: Displaying lines involves drawing a continuous line on a map that connects multiple points. This feature is commonly used to represent routes, boundaries, or paths. By displaying lines, users can visualize connections and trace specific routes on the map for navigation or data representation purposes.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_about.text: Displaying a polygon allows users to create closed shapes with straight lines on a map. This feature is commonly used to define boundaries, areas of interest, or regions. By displaying polygons, users can visually represent and interact with specific geographic areas, providing valuable context and information on the map.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_about.text: Displaying a circle feature enables users to draw circular shapes on a map. This functionality is frequently employed to represent areas of influence, proximity, or coverage. By displaying circles, users can visually depict and interact with specific circular regions, providing valuable spatial information and analysis on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_about.text: Displaying a heatmap allows users to visualize and analyze data density on a map. This feature represents data using color gradients, with warmer colors indicating high density and cooler colors indicating lower density. Displaying a heatmap helps identify patterns, trends, and hotspots within the data, aiding in data exploration and decision-making.

codeSnippets_routing_services_about.text: Calculating a route involves using routing algorithms to determine the optimal path between two or more locations on a map. By considering factors like distance, traffic, and transportation mode, users can obtain navigation instructions that guide them efficiently from the starting point to the destination, assisting with route planning and navigation.

codeSnippets_places_search_about.text: Searching for places allows users to find specific locations or points of interest on a map. By entering keywords or addresses, users can discover relevant places, such as businesses, landmarks, or addresses. This feature helps users explore and locate desired destinations, enhancing the usability and functionality of the map application or website.

trackers_and_geofences_application_descr.text: In addition, the ping rate of your device position updates may influence all 3 three cost components depending on your application.

migrateAniOSApp_heading.text: iOS - Migrating from Google Maps to Amazon Location Service

migrateAniOSApp_desc.text: This guide details the technical process for transitioning iOS applications from Google Maps to Amazon Location Service. It highlights initial setup, Amazon Location resource configuration, and provides SDK comparison examples to facilitate the integration of mapping functionalities into iOS-based platforms.

migrateAniOSApp_desc1.text: The AWS documentation is a key resource for developers to master Amazon Location Service, providing a complete guide on features, setup, and integration. Check out the <0>official guide</0> for practical insights on adding location services to apps.

initiating_a_swift_iOS_dec.text: For this guide, we will use an iOS App project with a Storyboard UI in XCode, a comprehensive development environment that provides the necessary tools for creating engaging iOS applications using Swift.

integrating_the_iOS_amazon_location_sdk_.text: To enhance your application with Amazon Location Service's map functionalities, you need to incorporate the following packages into your Xcode iOS project:
The AWS SDK Swift package, designed for various Amazon web services including Amazon Location, enables the various features some of which are implemented in this document:
By integrating these packages, you can leverage the robustness of Amazon Location Service and MapLibre to create a feature-rich, interactive map experience for your application users.

For developers looking to explore the different SDK programming language options available for integrating Amazon Location Service into your application, click <0>here</0> to find detailed information that will help you select the right SDK tailored to your project's needs.

webSdkExamples_iOS_description.text: This guide features a variety of code examples tailored to distinct platforms, each addressing a prevalent use case. The primary objective is to facilitate the transition of your iOS application from Google Maps iOS SDK to Amazon Location Service, leveraging the capabilities of <1>MapLibre</1> and <1>AWS-SDK-Swift</1>. Specifically, the code samples about iOS applications are presented in the Swift programming language.

webSdkExample_iOS_description1.text: To proceed with the implementation of the examples provided, you will need to replace the existing content in the <1>ViewController.swift</1> with the code snippets from each example. This process will allow you to incorporate the specific functionalities demonstrated in the examples into your application.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_iOS_about.text: Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service offer robust solutions for integrating dynamic, customizable maps into your applications. These maps are capable of showcasing a wide array of geographical data, enriching the user experience with interactive features such as panning and zooming.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_iOS_point1.text: Google Maps uses <1>GMSMapView</1> to render maps.

codeSnippets_load_a_map_iOS_point2.text: Amazon Location Service uses MapLibre's <1>MLNMapView</1> to render maps.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_ios_about.text: Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service offer the functionality to plot markers at specific coordinates on a map, an essential feature for highlighting points of interest.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_ios_point1.text: Google Maps provides this feature natively, without the need for additional libraries or tools. It employs the <1>GMSMarker</1> class, which allows developers to instantiate and customize markers that can be placed at any longitude and latitude on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_ios_point2.text: In contrast, Amazon Location Service leverages the power of the MapLibre library to render markers onto the map. This is achieved using the <1>MLNPointAnnotation</1> class and the <1>addAnnotation</1> method. <1>MLNPointAnnotation</1> is a flexible tool that not only allows the placement of markers but also offers a range of customization options. The <1>addAnnotation</1> method is then used to add these custom annotations to the map, providing a highly interactive and dynamic map experience for users.

codeSnippets_adding_a_marker_ios_postDes.text: These marker-plotting capabilities enable developers to create interactive, location-aware applications that can guide users to specific points of interest, highlight geographical data, or provide location-based services.

codeSnippets_marker_clustering_ios_about.text: Marker clustering is a powerful feature provided by both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service, enhancing the visual clarity of maps with a high density of markers.

codeSnippets_marker_clustering_ios_descr.text: Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service provide marker clustering.

codeSnippets_marker_clustering_ios_point.text: Google Maps employs the <1>GMUClusterManager</1> class for this purpose. This class takes a reference to the map and the GMUDefaultClusterRenderer to effectively cluster markers on the map. This feature allows for the efficient rendering and management of large numbers of markers, thereby improving the user experience by reducing visual clutter and enhancing the performance of the map.

In contrast, Amazon Location Service achieves marker clustering through the MapLibre library. This is done using the <1>MLNSymbolStyleLayer</1> in conjunction with a <1>MLNShapeSource</1>. By setting the cluster option to true when creating the <1>MLNShapeSource</1>, you can enable marker clustering. Subsequently, expressions are used to style the <1>MLNSymbolStyleLayer</1> based on the cluster's point count. This is achieved using <1>NSExpression</1> to apply styles dynamically based on the number of points in each cluster. Note that handling taps on clusters and expanding them into individual markers would require additional logic, offering the possibility of a more interactive and user-friendly map experience.

codeSnippets_marker_clustering_ios_postD.text: By integrating these marker clustering capabilities, developers can significantly improve the usability and performance of their maps, particularly when dealing with large sets of data points.

codeSnippets_display_an_info_window_ios_.text: The ability to display an information popup for map markers is a key feature of interactive maps, and both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service offer robust solutions to implement this functionality.

In Google Maps, you can employ the <1>GMSMapView.selectedMarker</1> property to display the information associated with a specific marker. This feature allows users to interact with the map markers and access additional details, enhancing the overall user experience by providing contextually relevant information.

Amazon Location Service uses the <1>MLNMapView.selectAnnotation</1> property for a similar purpose. By setting this property, you can display the information related to a specific marker. However, to ensure the information popup is displayed, you also need to override the <1>annotationCanShowCallout</1> function and return true. This approach provides a high degree of flexibility, allowing developers to customize the information displayed and control its presentation based on specific conditions.
Through the integration of these features, developers can significantly enhance the interactivity of their maps, providing users with valuable insights and context about specific locations or points.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_ios_about.text: Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service provide comprehensive tools to add lines, enhancing the visual representation of routes or boundaries on your map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_ios_postD.text: By incorporating these lines, developers can significantly enhance the map's interactivity and usefulness, offering users a visually rich representation of routes or geographical boundaries.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polyline_ios_point.text: Google Maps offers the Shapes class, which can be used to draw lines and polygons. This is achieved through the GMSPolyline class, a powerful tool that allows developers to define a series of coordinates and connect them with lines. This feature can be particularly useful for representing routes or boundaries within your application.

On the other hand, Amazon Location Service employs the MapLibre GL library for similar functionality. The MLNPolyline method can be used to add lines for a given set of coordinates. This method offers flexibility and precision, allowing developers to create complex shapes and routes on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_ios_about.text: Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service offer robust capabilities to add polygons to your maps, enabling developers to delineate specific areas or regions.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_ios_point1.text: Google Maps provides the Shapes class, a versatile tool that facilitates the drawing of both lines and polygons. The <1>GMSPolygon</1> class is specifically designed to create polygons, which can be customized to represent a particular area or region on the map. This feature is highly beneficial for applications that require the demarcation of specific geographical areas.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_ios_point2.text: In contrast, Amazon Location Service uses the MapLibre library for similar functionality. The <1>MLNPolygon</1> method can be used to add a polygon for a given set of coordinates. This method offers a high degree of flexibility and precision, allowing developers to create complex shapes and regions on the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_polygon_ios_postDe.text: By integrating these polygon features, developers can offer users a more comprehensive and detailed view of specific geographical areas, thereby enhancing the overall coordinates.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_ios_point1.text: Google Maps provides the <1>GMSCircle</1> class, specifically designed for this purpose. This class allows developers to define a circle with a specific radius around a given point, offering a straightforward and efficient way to highlight a particular area on the map.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_ios_point2.text: Amazon Location Service, on the other hand, employs a slightly different approach. It uses the <1>MLNCircleStyleLayer</1> and <1>MLNShapeSource</1> classes in conjunction with the circle-source and circle-layer identifiers. This combination provides a high degree of flexibility and precision, enabling developers to create customized circles on the map that can be dynamically updated based on data sources.

codeSnippets_drawing_a_circle_ios_postDe.text: By integrating these features, developers can enhance the user's map experience, offering a visually intuitive way to represent areas of interest or regions within a specific radius.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_ios_about.text: Heatmaps are valuable visualization tools that allow for the representation of data intensity across geographical areas. Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service offer comprehensive solutions to integrate this feature.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_ios_postDe.text: By integrating these heatmap capabilities, developers can provide users with a visually intuitive and detailed understanding of data patterns across geographical regions, thereby enhancing the overall user experience.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_ios_point1.text: Google Maps leverages the Shapes class, specifically the <1>GMUHeatmapTileLayer</1> class, to facilitate the creation of heatmaps. This class enables developers to define a collection of data points and a corresponding color gradient, which is then processed to generate a heatmap. This tool is particularly useful in representing data density or intensity across various regions within the map.

codeSnippets_adding_a_heatmap_ios_point2.text: In contrast, Amazon Location Service uses the capabilities of the MapLibre GL library to achieve a similar outcome. The <1>MLNHeatmapStyleLayer</1> class is used for creating heatmaps, offering a significant degree of flexibility and customization. To use this feature, you need to create a data source for the heatmap, which should be an array of <1>MLNPointFeature</1> objects. Each feature in this array represents a data point in the heatmap, allowing for a detailed and precise representation of data intensity.

codeSnippets_routing_services_ios_about.text: Routing services are essential components of mapping applications, providing users with directions between different locations. Both Google Maps and Amazon Location Service offer robust solutions for this functionality.

codeSnippets_routing_services_ios_point1.text: Google Maps provides <1>directions</1> or <1>computeRoutes</1> to calculate and display route data on the map.

codeSnippets_routing_services_ios_point2.text: In contrast, Amazon Location Service leverages the <1>aws-sdk-swift</1> library for its routing service. Developers can use the <1>AuthHelper.withAPIKey(apiKey, region)</1> function to initialize the <1>AuthHelper</1> with their APIKey, then create a <1>GeoRoutesClient(config: authHelper.getGeoRoutesClientConfig())</1> object to create a <1>CalculateRoutesInput</1> object. This object, containing the necessary parameters such as origin, destination, and travel mode, is then passed to the <1>geoRoutesClient.calculateRoutes</1> method to calculate the route. This approach provides a high degree of flexibility, allowing developers to customize the routing service to suit their specific needs.

codeSnippets_routing_services_ios_postDe.text: By integrating these routing services, developers can significantly enhance the functionality of their applications, providing users with detailed routes to your application.

codeSnippets_places_search_ios_about.text: Searching for places is an essential feature of today's mapping services. Google Maps and Amazon Location Service each provide comprehensive tools that enable users to carry out these searches effectively.

codeSnippets_places_search_ios_postDescr.text: By incorporating these place search features, developers can significantly enhance the utility of their applications, providing users with the ability to discover and navigate to places of interest effectively.

codeSnippets_places_search_ios_point1.text: Google Maps offers the <1>nearbysearch</1> API, a powerful tool designed to perform proximity-based searches. This feature allows users to search for places within a specified radius of a location, providing a list of places that match the search criteria. This can be particularly useful for applications that need to guide users to nearby points of interest or services.

codeSnippets_places_search_ios_point2.text: Conversely, Amazon Location Service leverages the <1>aws-sdk-swift</1> library to provide a similar functionality. Developers can use the <1>AuthHelper.withAPIKey(apiKey, region)</1> function to initialize the <1>AuthHelper</1> with their APIKey, then create a <1>GeoPlacesClient(config: authHelper.getGeoPlacesClientConfig())</1> object to create a <1>SuggestInput</1> object. This object is then passed to the <1>geoPlacesClient.suggest</1> method to execute the search. This approach provides a high degree of flexibility, allowing developers to customize the search parameters to suit their specific needs.

Its standout feature is the rapid display of maps, made achievable by harnessing the power of GPU-accelerated vector tile rendering. This ensures swift and efficient map presentation within your applications, providing a visually appealing and responsive mapping experience for users. MapLibre Native empowers you to effortlessly incorporate maps into your software projects while leveraging advanced technology for optimal performance. Its capabilities include:

webServices_article_items_examples_descr.text: When migrating from Google Maps to Amazon Location Service, it's important to understand the comparable services and API endpoints provided by each. While the two services offer similar geolocation features, the structure of the API requests and the naming conventions used can differ.

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_descripti.text: Map tiles are the way web maps (like Google Maps and Maplibre) are structured. They are square bitmap graphics displayed in a grid arrangement to show a map. Each tile is a small image, and contains a particular part of the map, at a specific level of detail or zoom level. When you zoom in or out of a web map, you're essentially loading different sets of tiles that have different levels of detail.

Map tile APIs, such as those provided by Google Maps and Amazon Location, allow developers to retrieve these map tiles programmatically. This can be useful for a variety of applications, such as creating a custom map viewer, embedding a map view in a webpage, or performing analyses on the geographic information contained in the tiles.

The APIs work by accepting HTTP requests that specify the desired map type (e.g., roadmap, satellite), the geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), and the zoom level. The API then returns the corresponding map tile as an image file (usually PNG or JPEG format).
In the context of map tiles, Z, X, and Y are parameters that determine the specific tile you're retrieving from a map. Here's what each one represents:

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_point1.text: Z (Zoom level): This parameter determines the scale of the map. A higher zoom level will show a smaller area in more detail. For example, at a high zoom level, you might see street names and individual buildings. At a lower zoom level, you might only see country borders and large cities. The zoom level is often represented as an exponent of 2, so a zoom level of n will result in the map being divided into 2^n x 2^n tiles.

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_point2.text: X (Column): This parameter determines the longitudinal (east-west) position of the tile. At zoom level 0, there is only one tile, so the X value is 0. At higher zoom levels, the X value can range from 0 to 2^Z - 1, moving from west to east.

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_point3.text: Y (Row): This parameter determines the latitudinal (north-south) position of the tile. Like the X value, the Y value ranges from 0 to 2^Z - 1 at each zoom level, but it moves from north to south.

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_postDescr.text: Together, these parameters can specify any tile on the map at any level of detail. By changing these parameters, you can navigate to different parts of the map and zoom in or out.

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_request_s.text: In Google Maps, the first step is to create a session. This is done via a POST request that includes the map type, language, and region. The map type can be 'roadmap', 'satellite', etc. The language and region parameters are used to localize the map tiles.

Once the session is created, you can then retrieve the map tiles. This is done via a GET request that includes the zoom level (Z), the x-coordinate (X), and the y-coordinate (Y). The session token generated in the previous step is also required.
<0>The response to this request is a PNG file containing the requested map tile.</0>
With Amazon Location, getting map tiles is a simple process. It involves a single GET request that includes the map name, zoom level (Z), x-coordinate (X), and y-coordinate (Y).
<0>The returned blob contains Mapbox Vector Tile (MVT) data</0>

The response to this request includes HTTP headers indicating the cache control policy and content type, followed by the map tile data (referred to as a "blob"). The map tile data can be used to render the map tile in a suitable application.

codeSnippets_geocoding_description.text: Geocoding is the process of converting addresses into geographic coordinates. This is a key feature in many applications that require location data.

codeSnippets_geocoding_withGoogle_descri.text: In Google Maps, the Geocoding API is used to convert addresses into <0>geographic</0> coordinates. The geocode endpoint is used for this purpose. It does allow you to bias results to a certain region using the region or components parameters.

The components allowing you to filter results by political or geographical components, such as <0>administrative_area</0>, <0>locality</0>, or <0>postal_code</0>. For example, <0>components=locality:Mountain+View|country:US</0> would bias the results towards the locality of Mountain View in the US. Here's an example of a geocoding request in Google Maps:

codeSnippets_geocoding_withAmazon_descri.text: In Amazon Location Service, the comparable feature to Google Maps' geocoding is the <0>SearchPlaceIndexForText</0> operation. This operation searches for places using free-form text (like an address) and returns candidate places along with supplementary information. A simple request contains the following required parameter:
Text – An address, name, city, or region to convert to a set of coordinates. For example, the string 'Any Town'.
To specify a maximum number of results per page, use the following optional parameter:
MaxResults – Limits the maximum number of results returned in the query response.
FilterCountries – The country or region you want to geocode within. You can define up to 100 countries in one request using a ISO 3166 three letter country code.

codeSnippets_geocoding_withAmazon_reques.text: In this request, the Text field is equivalent to the input parameter in Google Maps, specifying the address to be geocoded. The <1>BiasPosition</1> and <1>FilterCountries</1> field is used to bias the search results to a specific area, similar to the <1>locationbias</1> and <1>Country</1> parameters in Google Maps. The key parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our geocoding service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

web_services_app_responseComparison_tabl.text: The full text of the returned address.

codeSnippets_reverse_geocoding_descripti.text: Another key feature provided by both services is Reverse Geocoding, which involves converting geographic coordinates into a human-readable address or place name. This feature is often used in applications that need to display location information in a format that is easily understood by users.

codeSnippets_reverse_geocoding_withGoogl.text: In Google Maps, the <0>geocode</0> endpoint of the Places API is also used for reverse geocoding. However you need to use <0>latlng</0> to provide position for reverse geocoding. Here's an example of a reverse geocoding request in Google Maps:

codeSnippets_reverse_geocoding_withAmazo.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <0>SearchPlaceIndexForPosition</0> operation is used for reverse geocoding. This operation searches for places around a specified position. A simple request contains the following required parameter:
Position – A set of coordinates that you want to convert to an address, point of interest, or general location. Defined using the format <0>[longitude, latitude]</0>.
To specify a maximum number of results per page, add the following optional parameter:
MaxResults – Limits the maximum number of results returned in the query response.
If you want to specify a preferred language for the results of your query, use the following optional parameter:
Language – A language code to be used for rendering results. The value must be a valid BCP 47 language code. For example, en for English.
Here's an example of a reverse geocoding request in Amazon Location Service:

In this request, the Position field is equivalent to the location parameter in Google Maps, specifying the geographic coordinates to be reverse geocoded. The <1>MaxResults</1> field specifies the maximum number of results to return. The <1>Language</1> field specifies the language in which the results should be returned, similar to the language parameter in Google Maps. The key parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our reverse geocoding service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

The latitude and longitude of the location.
The full text description or name of the address component.
The type of the address component.

web_services_app_note_description.text: The <0>results[]</0> in Google Maps and <0>Results[]</0> in Amazon Location Service are arrays containing the reverse geocoding results. Each element in the array represents one place that matches the search criteria. - The <0>*</0> in <0>Results[].Place.*</0> represents various fields like <0>AddressNumber</0>, <0>Neighborhood</0>, <0>Municipality</0>, <0>SubRegion</0>, <0>Region</0>, <0>Country</0>, <0>PostalCode</0> in Amazon

codeSnippets_text_searching_description.text: Text searching is a feature that allows users to search for places using textual queries. Both Google Maps and Amazon Location provide this feature, albeit with different request structures and responses.

codeSnippets_text_searching_withGoogle_d.text: The Google Maps text search request is made using a POST HTTP method. The request body contains the textQuery field which specifies the location to be searched. The request headers include the <0>Content-Type</0>, <0>X-Goog-Api-Key</0> (for authentication), and <0>X-Goog-FieldMask</0> (to specify which fields to include in the response).

The response from Google Maps includes an array of places that match the search query. Each place has a <0>formattedAddress</0> and a <0>displayName</0> which includes the <0>text</0> and <0>languageCode</0>.

codeSnippets_text_searching_withAmazon_d.text: The Amazon Location text search request is made via <0>SearchPlaceIndexForText</0> service using a POST HTTP method. This service request body contains the Text field for the location to be searched, <0>BiasPosition</0> to bias the search towards a particular geographic region, and Language to specify the language of the search. This service also supports various body parameters such as:
For more comprehensive information regarding our text search service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_nearby_searching_withAmazon.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <0>SearchPlaceIndexForPosition</0> operation is used for reverse geocoding. This operation searches for places around a specified position.

Position – A set of coordinates that you want to convert to an address, point of interest, or general location. Defined using the format <0>[longitude,latitude]</0>.

codeSnippets_calculating-a-route_descrip.text: Calculating routes, which is crucial in applications that require navigation or travel distance information.

codeSnippets_calculating-a-route_googleM.text: In Google Maps, You can use <0>v2:computeRoutes</0> API. The request headers include the <0>Content-Type</0>, <0>X-Goog-Api-Key</0> (for authentication), and <0>X-Goog-FieldMask</0> (to specify which fields to include in the response). Here is an example of calculate route request in Google Maps:

codeSnippets_calculating-a-route_withAma.text: In Amazon Location Service, the CalculateRoute operation is used to calculate routes. When calculating a route, you can specify up to 23 intermediate stopover points between the departure position and the destination position using waypoint positions.
WaypointPositions – Specifies an ordered list of intermediate positions to include along a route between the departure position and destination position.
Note: If you specify a waypoint position that's not located on a road, Amazon Location moves the position to the nearest road.
The following CalculateRoute request calculates a route with 2 waypoints:
The departure position is <0>[-122.7565, 49.0021]</0>, and the destination position is <0>[-122.3394, 47.6159]</0>.
The first stop over position is <0>[-122.1884, 48.0936]</0>.
The second stop over position is <0>[-122.3493, 47.6205]</0>.
To include the leg linestring geometry between these two waypoints, set the following optional parameter to true:
IncludeLegGeometry – Includes the geometry of each path between a pair of positions in the response.
Here's an example of a CalculateRoute request in Amazon Location Service:

In this request, the DeparturePosition field is equivalent to the origin parameter in Google Maps, specifying the starting point for the route calculation. The <1>DestinationPosition</1> field is equivalent to the destination parameter in Google Maps, specifying the endpoint. The key parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our routing service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_route-planning_googleMap_de.text: In Google Maps, You can use the <0>v2:computeRoutes</0> API for calculating the route matrix. The request headers include the <0>Content-Type</0>, <0>X-Goog-Api-Key</0> (for authentication), and <0>X-Goog-FieldMask</0> (to specify which fields to include in the response). codeSnippets_route-planning_withAmazon_d.text: Amazon Location Service provides a similar functionality with its Route Matrix API. It allows developers to calculate distances and travel times between multiple start and end points. Unlike Google Maps, Amazon Location Service uses a POST request to fetch this data. The request includes a JSON payload with departure positions, destination positions, and the unit for distance measurement.
Calculate route matrix request can be made by using the <0>CalculateRouteMatrix</0> operation. A minimal request contains the following required fields:
DeparturePositions – The set of starting positions for which to calculate the routes. Defined as an array of [longitude, latitude]
DestinationPositions – The set of end positions for which to calculate the routes. Defined as an array of [longitude, latitude].
By default, the response returns Distance in kilometers. You can change the unit of measurement to miles using the following optional parameter:
DistanceUnit – Specifies the unit system to use for the distance results.
Here is an example of an Amazon Location Service Route Matrix API request:

codeSnippets_route-planning_withAmazon_p.text: In this request, the DeparturePositions and DestinationPositions are arrays of latitude-longitude pairs. The DistanceUnit parameter defines the unit of measurement (in this case, miles are used). For more comprehensive information regarding our route planning service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_route-planning_responseResu.text: From the comparison, it's clear that while Google Maps and Amazon Location Service have differences in their naming conventions and response structures, they offer similar functionalities for route planning. This understanding is crucial for a successful migration from Google Maps to Amazon Location Service.

codeSnippets_route_matrix_about.text: A route matrix service is like a smart assistant for maps that helps figure out the best way to get from one place to another. It not only calculates the distance between different locations but also tells you how long it might take to travel between them. This can be super handy for apps that need to plan routes, find the quickest path, or optimize travel logistics. Basically, it makes navigating through maps smoother and helps applications provide users with the most efficient travel options.

migrationOverview_heading.text: Migrate from Google Maps to Amazon Location

migrationOverview_subHeading.text: This article provides insights on how to migrate web, mobile, and server-based applications from Google Maps to the Amazon Location platform. This tutorial includes comparative code samples, migration suggestions, and best practices for migrating to Amazon Location.

migrationOverview_featuresList2_desc.text: Protect user privacy, shield your sensitive information, and reduce your application’s security risks.

migrationOverview_serviceOverview_desc.text: Amazon Location Service is a fully managed location service that provides developers with the ability to add location data and functionality to their applications. The service includes a set of REST APIs that offer a variety of features, including:

migrationOverview_serviceOverview_point1.text: Maps: Fetch vector and raster maps in multiple styles and satellite imagery.

migrationOverview_serviceOverview_point2.text: Places: Search for and get information about places of interest, such as businesses, restaurants, and attractions.

migrationOverview_serviceOverview_point3.text: Routes: Calculate optimal routes for travel, taking into account traffic conditions and other factors.

migrationOverview_serviceOverview_point4.text: Geofences: Create and manage geofences, which are virtual boundaries that can trigger actions when a device enters or leaves the boundary.

migrationOverview_serviceOverview_point5.text: Trackers: Track the location of devices and receive notifications when they enter or leave geofences.

migrationOverview_serviceComparison_desc.text: These tables provide a high-level list of Amazon Location features, which correspond to Google Maps features. This list doesn't show all Amazon Location features, such as geofences and trackers.
Amazon Location Service supports two methods of integration, a direct SDK integration as well as REST service APIs.

migrationOverview_featureComparison_desc.text: Google Maps and Amazon Location are both location-based services that offer a range of features to enhance location-based experiences. From mapping and geocoding to routing and geofencing capabilities, these services empower developers to build applications with accurate and personalized location services. <0>Learn more</0>

migrationOverview_migrationConsideration.text: When migrating to Amazon Location Service from Google Maps, consider the following points:
The Amazon Location Map resource gives you access to the underlying base map data for a map. You will need a map rendering library such as <0>Maplibre</0> to add interactive maps to your application.

Amazon Location provides map tiles from different map providers and you can choose accordingly based on the needs of your application. <0>Learn more</0> about how those data providers might fit into your licensing considerations.

Amazon Location charges for the usage of interactive maps, which is based on the number of loaded map tiles. In the interactive Amazon Location SDK along with Maplibre, map tiles are automatically cached to reduce the development cost.
The Amazon Location and MapLibre SDKs use map tiles. Unless the user pans and zooms the map, they are only charged for the number of tiles that they fetch.
Amazon Location stores its data in AWS.
Here are some related resources for Amazon Location:

migrationOverview_authentication_desc.text: Google Maps provides basic key-based authentication. Amazon Location Service provides both basic key-based authentication and AWS Cognito authentication. AWS Cognito authentication provides more security features than the basic key-based authentication.

migrationOverview_authentication_point1_.text: The <0>basic key-based authentication</0> allows you to simply plug in your API key and authorizes the following actions:

migrationOverview_authentication_point2.text: The <0>AWS Cognito authentication</0> method on the other hand gives you much more granular control and allows you to access all resources depending on your privacy policy.

migrationOverview_suggestedMigrationPlan.text: A high-level migration plan consists of these steps.
Take inventory of the Google Maps APIs and services that your application uses. Verify that Amazon Location provides alternative APIs and services.
Review the technical resources and migration support below for specific details and assistance.
Create an <0>AWS account</0> and <1>API key</1> or <2>Amazon Cognito setup</2>.
Deploy your migrated application to production.

migrationSDK_description.text: The Amazon Location Migration SDK provides a bridge that allows you to migrate existing applications from Google Maps to Amazon Location. The Migration SDK provides an option for your application built using the Google Maps SDK for JavaScript to use Amazon Location Service without needing to rewrite any of the application or business logic if Amazon Location supports the capabilities used. The Migration SDK redirects all API calls to the Amazon Location instead of Google Maps. If you'd like to try out the Migration SDK on your existing application before beginning your full migration, see the <0>Amazon Location Migration SDK on GitHub.</0>

codeSnippets_snapping_to_roads_ios_point.text: Google Maps provides a <1>snapToRoads</1> endpoint from the Roads API.
Amazon Location Service provides a <1>SnapToRoads</1> service from the <1>AWSGeoRoutes</1> API.

migrateAWebApp_prerequisites_point_5_c_i.text: Resources and actions: Actions authorized by this key. You must specify actions for the respective resources.

codeSnippets_geocoding_withAmazon_descri.text: In Amazon Location Service, the comparable feature to Google Maps' geocoding is the <0>Geocode</0> service using an HTTP POST request. This service searches for places using free-form text (like an address) and returns coordinates, addresses, and other supplementary information about the candidate places. A simple request contains the following required parameter:
QueryText – An address, name, city, or region to convert to a set of coordinates. For example, the string 'Any Town'.

codeSnippets_geocoding_withAmazon_reques.text: In this request, the <1>QueryText</1> field is equivalent to the input parameter in Google Maps, specifying the address to be geocoded. The <1>BiasPosition</1> and <1>FilterCountries</1> field are used to bias the search results to a specific area, similar to the <1>locationbias</1> and <1>Country</1> parameters in Google Maps. The <1>key</1> parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our geocoding service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_reverse_geocoding_withAmazo.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <0>ReverseGeocode</0> service is used for reverse geocoding via an HTTP POST request. This API uses coordinates to retrieve addresses and place information. A simple request contains the following required parameter:
QueryPosition – A set of coordinates that you want to convert to an address, point of interest, or general location. Defined using the format <0>[longitude, latitude]</0>.

In this request, the <1>QueryPosition</1> field is equivalent to the <1>location</1> parameter in Google Maps, specifying the geographic coordinates to be reverse geocoded. The <1>MaxResults</1> field specifies the maximum number of results to return. The <1>Language</1> field specifies the language in which the results should be returned, similar to the <1>language</1> parameter in Google Maps. The <1>key</1> parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our reverse geocoding service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_text_searching_withAmazon_d.text: The Amazon Location text search request is made via <1>SearchText</1> service using an HTTP POST request. The request body contains the <1>QueryText</1> field for the location to be searched, <1>BiasPosition</1> to bias the search towards a particular geographic region, and <1>Language</1> to specify the language of the search. For more comprehensive information regarding our text search service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_nearby_searching_withAmazon.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <0>SearchNearby</0> service is used for nearby searching via an HTTP POST request, This service searches for places around a specified position. A simple request contains the following required parameter:
QueryPosition – A set of coordinates that you want to convert to an address, point of interest, or general location. Defined using the format <0>[longitude,latitude]</0>.

codeSnippets_nearby_searching_request_de.text: In this request, the <1>QueryPosition</1> field is equivalent to the <1>location</1> parameter in Google Maps. The <1>MaxResults</1> field specifies the maximum number of results to return. The <1>Language</1> field specifies the language in which the results should be returned, similar to the <1>language</1> parameter in Google Maps. The <1>key</1> parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our text search service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_autocomplete_withAmazon_des.text: In Amazon Location Service, the comparable feature to Google Maps' autocomplete is the <0>Autocomplete</0> service, called using a POST HTTP method. This service provides autocomplete functionality for text-based geographic searches, returning place predictions in response to user search queries. A simple request contains the following required parameter:
QueryText - The free form text query making up the partial address to be completed.

In this request, the <1>QueryText</1> field is equivalent to the <1>input</1> parameter in Google Maps, specifying the text string on which to search. The <1>MaxResults</1> field specifies the maximum number of results to return. The <1>key</1> parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our autocomplete service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_suggest_places_desc.text: This finds suggested addresses or place candidates based on an incomplete or misspelled query, from which you select the best query.

codeSnippets_suggest_places_googleDesc.text: In Google Maps, the <1>places:autocomplete</1> endpoint of the Places API is used for this purpose along with the <1>includeQueryPredictions</1> parameter set to <1>true</1>.

codeSnippets_suggest_places_amazonDesc.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <1>Suggest</1> service is used via an HTTP POST request.

codeSnippets_suggest_places_amazonPostDe.text: For more comprehensive information regarding this service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_get-place-details_descripti.text: Given a unique place ID, you can retrieve extended information about that specific location.

codeSnippets_get-place-details_withGoogl.text: In Google Maps, the <1>places/place_id</1> endpoint of the Place Details API is used for this purpose.

codeSnippets_get-place-details_withAmazo.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <1>GetPlace</1> service is used to retrieve place details via an HTTP GET request.

In this request, <1>PlaceId</1> is the unique identifier of the place whose details are to be retrieved, equivalent to the <1>place_id</1> parameter in Google Maps. The <1>key</1> parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our place details service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_getting_map_tiles_request_s.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <1>GetMapTile</1> service is used via an HTTP GET request that includes the <1>Tileset</1> which can either be <1>raster.satellite</1> or <1>vector.basemap</1>, zoom level <1>Z</1>, x-coordinate <1>X</1>, and y-coordinate <1>Y</1>.

The response to this request includes HTTP headers indicating the cache control policy and content type, followed by the map tile data referred to as a blob which represents either a vector tile in <1>mvt</1> format or a raster tile in <1>png</1> format. This can be used to render the map tile in a suitable application.

codeSnippets_get_static_map_desc.text: This allows you to embed a map image on your web page without requiring JavaScript or any dynamic page loading.

codeSnippets_get_static_map_googleDesc.text: In Google Maps, the <1>staticmap</1> endpoint of the Maps API is used for this purpose.

codeSnippets_get_static_map_amazonDesc.text: In Amazon Location Service, the comparable feature to Google Maps’ <1>staticmap</1> is the <1>GetStaticMap</1> service using an HTTP GET request.

codeSnippets_calculating-a-route_withAma.text: In Amazon Location Service, the <1>CalculateRoutes</1> service is used to calculate routes by using an HTTP POST request. When calculating a route, you can specify up to 100 intermediate stopover points between the origin and the destination positions using waypoints. The following parameters are required:
Origin - The start position for the route.
Destination - The finish position for the route.

LegGeometryFormat – Chooses what the returned Route leg geometry format should be. Can be FlexiblePolyline or Simple, defaults to FlexiblePolyline, which is a compressed geometry format that is used to make the responses smaller.
The origin position is <0>[-122.7565, 49.0021]</0>, and the destination position is <0>[-122.3394, 47.6159]</0>.

In this request, the <1>Origin</1> field is equivalent to the <1>origin</1> parameter in Google Maps, specifying the starting point for the route calculation. The <1>Destination</1> field is equivalent to the <1>destination</1> parameter in Google Maps, specifying the endpoint. The <1>key</1> parameter is your API key. For more comprehensive information regarding our routing service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_optimizing_waypoints_desc.text: This allows calculating of the optimal order to travel between a set of waypoints to minimize either the travel time or the distance traveled during the journey based on road network restrictions and the traﬃc pattern data.

codeSnippets_optimizing_waypoints_google.text: In Google Maps, the <1>v2:computeRoutes</1> endpoint of the Routes API is used for this purpose along with the <1>optimizeWaypointOrder</1> parameter set to <1>true</1>.

codeSnippets_optimizing_waypoints_amazon.text: In Amazon Location Service this can be accomplished with <1>OptimizeWaypoints</1> service using an HTTP POST request.
For more comprehensive information regarding our optimizing waypoints service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_snapping_to_roads_desc.text: The snap to roads matches a GPS trace to the nearest road by returning a similar set of data, with the points snapped to the most likely roads the vehicle was traveling along.

codeSnippets_snapping_to_roads_googleDes.text: In Google Maps, <1>snapToRoads</1> endpoint of the Roads API is used which requires a <1>path</1> parameter that accepts a list of <1>latitude, longitude</1> pairs.

codeSnippets_snapping_to_roads_amazonDes.text: In Amazon Location Service, <1>SnapToRoads</1> service is used via an HTTP POST request along with <1>TracePoints</1> which is a list of trace points to be snapped onto the road network.

codeSnippets_snapping_to_roads_amazonPos.text: For more comprehensive information regarding our snap to roads service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_route-planning_withAmazon_p.text: In this request, the <1>Origins</1> and <1>Destinations</1> are arrays of objects which include Positions. For more comprehensive information regarding our route planning service, please refer to the detailed documentation provided <0>here</0>.

codeSnippets_route-planning_withAmazon_d.text: Amazon Location Service provides a similar functionality with its <1>CalculateRouteMatrix</1> service, called using an HTTP POST request. It allows developers to calculate distances and travel times between multiple start and end points. The results contain all combinations of Origins and Destinations. Each row corresponds to the route from the Origin to an entry in Destinations.
A minimal request contains the following required fields:
Origins – The set of starting positions for which to calculate the routes.
Destinations – The set of end positions for which to calculate the routes.

multiple_region_disclaimer.text: Disclaimer: when user's AWS account is connected, changing the region will only affect Maps, Places and Routes.

samples__js-quick-start-using-api-keys__.text: This sample app displays a map with reverse geocode functionality via API keys.
Open `main.js` and enter the API key and the region where the resources were created in.
If you would like to remove all of the resources created in this walkthrough, delete the CloudFormation stack called `js-quick-start-using-api-keys`.

samples__react-tracking-data-streaming__.text: Trackers and data streaming using React

This example demonstrates how to stream trackers data on a web map using React and react-map-gl. To create the necessary resources navigate to the github repo from above and run the templates under `src/cfn_template` to create resources required for this example.
Open `src/configuration.js` and enter the IdentityPoolId, API key and the region where the resources were created in.

Run `npm start` to start a local web server on [`localhost:3000`](http://localhost:3000/) with this
example and open it in a browser.

To remove all of the resources created in this walkthrough, delete the CloudFormation stack named
`react-tracking-data-streaming`.
